Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: REE: Makescape - A Constructionist Museum Installation to Advance Engineering Literacy

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to create a constructionist exhibit at the New York Hall of Science and use the exhibit to understand how informal engineering activities change students' pathways in ways that can eventually lead to more students pursuing engineering degrees, a current national priority. To understand the impact on students, particularly those in middle school, the project will log student activities and interaction with museum staff as well as collect post-visit data from participants.

The broader significance and importance of this project arises from the potential to inform how museum exhibits, which annually reach millions of students, can be used to increase the number of students who follow pathways to eventual engineering careers. The project will reach large numbers of students from groups currently under-represented in engineering degree programs. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by building the capacity of the nation's citizenry for addressing societal challenges through engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project created, iterated, and studied an interactive digital tabletop museum exhibit designed to introduce visitors to basic practices in electrical engineering. The exhibit, Oztoc, invited visitors to design and build glowing fishing lures from common electronic components (batteries, LEDs, resistors, etc.), so as to attract different kinds of (simulated) bioluminescent fish. The exhibit supports playful, idiosyncratic engagement in the content area. Visitors come to understand the purpose of different circuit components, and the principles of circuitry, by building and testing different circuits and by watching other visitors build and test different circuits.

The intellectual merits of our project include:

  1. Building a better understanding of the ways that novices learn engineering practices in shared, informal activities. This resulted in refined frameworks for guiding observations of collaborative learning activities.
  2. Formalizing best practices for how to support constructionist, creative activities within a STEM museum setting. This resulted in design guidelines for creating exhibits and mobile support applications to be used by museum staff.
  3. Exploring best practices in adapting new learning sciences research methods (including mixed methods, like qualitative observational codes and data mining) into informal engineering education contexts. This resulted in several proofs-of-concept for how data mining and modeling techniques can be used to make sense of logged visitor actions at exhibits.

 

The broader impacts include: the exhibit itself, frameworks, guidelines, and new research into understanding how people learn with creative museum exhibits. Our research and design guidelines have been disseminated widely to the learning sciences, engineering education, human-computer interaction, data mining, and informal learning practitioner communities. We used our exhibit as a testbed for a workshop convened to spark innovation in detecting and documenting learning in museum settings, and the project itself serves as an example of how formal and informal research institutions can work together to conduct meaningful live site research. Thousands of visitors to the New York Hall of Science were able to use the exhibit, and by virtue of their engagement, generate data that is useful for both revising the design of the exhibit and for informing our understanding of how visitors engage in engineering education tasks.
